questions.correct_answer: B. Short arm of chromosome Y
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Short arm of chromosome Y The SRY gene located on the short arm of the Y chromosome directly controls the differentiation of testis from the bipotential gonad. SRY expression occurs at the 5th to 6th week of development of the embryo. When SRY is not expressed ovarian development takes place in XX karyotype

Highyeild:

Sex-determining region Y protein (SRY), or testis-determining factor (TDF), is a DNA-binding protein (also known as gene-regulatory protein/transcription factor) encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination SRY is an intronless sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rubella (perinatal transmission) Rubella has the least risk of perinatal transmission

Highyeild:

Maximum risk of transmission in case of rubella is in the first trimester, causing abortions and severe fetal defects. Classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome is Deafness Cataract Congenital heart disease Rubella is transmitted primarily through direct or droplet contact from nasopharyngeal secretions. Humans are the only natural hosts. In temperate climates, infections usually occur during late winter and early spring.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Herpes simplex infection can be acquired in utero, intrapartum/perinatally, or during the neonatal period. The intrauterine infection causes skin vesicles, eye findings (chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis), and microcephaly/ hydra Intrapartum infection presents with either: Skin, eye, and mouth disease Encephalitis Disseminated disease with sepsis-like presentation Option B: Cytomegalovirus, the most common congenital infection with perinatal transmission presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequels is hearing loss. Option D: Hepatitis B virus is associated with significant perinatal transmission. The most important risk factor that determines perinatal transmission is HBeAg.

questions.correct_answer: A. Cystocele-colposuspension surgery performed in prolapse
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystocele-colposuspension surgery performed in prolapse The incorrectly matched option is cystocele - Colposuspension. The surgery performed for cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy.

Highyeild:

Delancey’s three levels of pelvic support

questions.text: A 38-year-old multi gravida presents with 2 years of infertility and dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas. What would be the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TVS The patient presenting with symptoms of dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea with a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of douglas is most likely suffering from endometriosis. Next best step in management is to perform TVS. Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis but it is not done routinely for diagnostic purposes.

Highyeild:

Tenderness on vaginal examination, palpable nodules in the posterior fornix, adnexal masses, and immobility of the uterus are diagnostically indicating findings of endometriosis Transvaginal ultrasound is a diagnostic tool with high sensitivity and specificity for ovarian endometriomas and permits a wide exploration of the pelvic cavity. Endometriomas appear as homogenous formations with a classic ground-glass appearance and low-level internal echoes. TVUS could moreover facilitate the diagnosis of deep infiltrating endometriosis located in the rectovaginal septum, uterosacral ligaments, pouch of Douglas, and vaginal wall Gold standard : Laparoscopy combined with an exploration of the abdominal cavity and a histological biopsy HSG is mainly used for checking tubal patency and detecting structural anomalies in the uterus

questions.text: A Pregnant woman comes for an antenatal checkup. She has a history of stillbirth at 28 weeks in her previous pregnancy. She also has a history of multiple sexual partners and vaguely remembers having a painless ulcer on her vulva prior to her last pregnancy. What would be the first step of investigation for this lady?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VDRL test History of painless vulvar ulcer in her last pregnancy and stillbirth at 28 weeks, with a history of multiple sexual partners is suggestive of Syphilis. The first step should be to do a confirmatory investigation which is VDRL

Highyeild:

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum Incubation period: 9 to 90 days Primary lesion: papules which progress to the genital ulcer (Hard chancre/ hunter Ian chancre) Single ulcer with clean base Induration present Nontender No bleeding on touch Inguinal lymph nodes: Bilaterally enlarged, non-tender, rubbery consistency Diagnosis: Dark field microscopy Secondary syphilis: Symmetric, non-pruritic, polymorphic rash over palms and soles Mucosal lesion: Condyloma Lata Snail liveck ulcer Latent & tertiary Syphilis- Gummatous syphilis: Rubbery nodules break to form ulcers with a punched-out edge Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Karyotyping analysis is not necessary in this condition Option: C. Pap smear should be performed when there is suspicion of Carcinoma cervix Option: D. USG has minimal diagnostic function in case of suspected syphilis

questions.text: What is the best fertility treatment.

options.label: A
options.text: Weight reduction Metformin + ovulation induction with clomiphene (Treatment of PCOD)

options.label: B
options.text: Weight reduction Metformin + ovulation induction with urine gonadotropins

options.label: C
options.text: Finasteride + metformin and wait for spontaneous conception

questions.correct_answer: A. Weight reduction Metformin + ovulation induction with clomiphene (Treatment of PCOD)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Weight reduction Metformin + ovulation induction with clomiphene (Treatment of PCOD) Metformin is a drug that can help some people lose weight by lowering the amount of insulin the body produces and improving insulin resistance. Clomiphene citrate is an oral medication that induces ovulation by blocking estrogen receptors. It increases the production of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) by the pituitary gland, thereby stimulating follicles and hence egg growth TREATMENT OF PCOD

Highyeild:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome /Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)/ Stein-Leventhal syndrome is a multisystem disorder. It involves metabolic and endocrine dysfunctions that commonly occur among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states. Important clinical features of PCOS are Menstrual abnormalities (70%) -oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, obesity,hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism, acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance, and infertility.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B, C and D are incorrect statement.

questions.text: About primary dysmenorrhoea Which one is correct ?

options.label: A
options.text: Starts few hours before menstruation to 24-72 hrs after

options.label: B
options.text: Starts 2 days before menstruation to just after menstruation

options.label: C
options.text: Associate with psychological factors. Primary Dysmenorrhea

options.label: D
options.text: GnRh antagonists are first line of treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. Associate with psychological factors. Primary Dysmenorrhea
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Associate with psychological factors. Primary Dysmenorrhea Primary dysmenorrhea is dependent on psychological factors. This is the true statement.

Highyeild:

Dysmenorrhea refers to painful menstrual cramps that occur just before or during menstruation. There are two main types of dysmenorrhea: primary dysmenorrhea and secondary dysmenorrhea. Primary Dysmenorrhea: Primary dysmenorrhea is the most common type of menstrual pain and typically starts a day or two before menstruation and lasts for 2-3 days. It usually begins a few years after a woman starts menstruating and may improve with age or after childbirth.The pain is usually crampy and is felt in the lower abdomen or pelvis. Other symptoms can include lower back pain, nausea, and sometimes diarrhea. The pain is caused by the release of prostaglandins, which are chemicals that promote uterine contractions. Higher levels of prostaglandins can lead to stronger contractions and more severe pain. Non-prescription pain relievers, like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), are often effective in managing primary dysmenorrhea by reducing prostaglandin levels and easing pain. Secondary Dysmenorrhea: Secondary dysmenorrhea is pain caused by an underlying medical condition, often involving the reproductive organs. It usually starts earlier in the menstrual cycle and lasts longer than primary dysmenorrhea. Conditions that can cause secondary dysmenorrhea include: Endometriosis: A condition in which tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus, causing pain, adhesions, and inflammation. Adenomyosis: A condition in which the tissue lining the uterus grows into the muscular wall of the uterus, causing heavy bleeding and pain. Fibroids: Noncancerous growths in the uterus that can cause pain and heavy bleeding. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): An infection of the reproductive organs that can cause pain, fever, and other symptoms. Ovarian Cysts: Fluid-filled sacs on the ovaries that can cause pain when they rupture or become large. Intrauterine Device (IUD): Some women may experience increased menstrual pain with certain types of IUDs. Dysmenorrhea include uterine fibroids, adenomyosis, and most commonly, endometriosis It is more common to have heavy periods, irregular periods, those whose periods started before twelve years of age and those who have a low body weight. A pelvic exam and ultrasound in individuals who are sexually active may be useful for diagnosis. Conditions that should be ruled out include ectopic pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease, interstitial cystitis and chronic pelviC PAIN Painful menstrual cramps can result from an excess of prostaglandins released from the uterus. Prostaglandins cause the uterine muscles to tighten and relax causing the menstrual cramps. This type of dysmenorrhea is called primary dysmenorrhea . Primary dysmenorrhea usually begins in the teens soon after the first period. MANAGEMENT OF DYSMENORRHOEA Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs should be used as first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea. Oral contraceptives may be effective for relieving symptoms of primary dysmenorrhea

Extraedge:

Review stated that high-frequency transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation may reduce pain compared with sham TENS, but seems to be less effective than ibuprofen

questions.text: What is the most common cause for puberty menorrhagia?

options.label: A
options.text: Anovulation common cause of puberty menorrhagia

questions.correct_answer: A. Anovulation common cause of puberty menorrhagia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anovulation common cause of puberty menorrhagia Most common cause of puberty menorrhagia is anovulatory cycles. Anovulatory cycles-unopposed estrogen-endometrial hyperplasia-prolonged and heavy periods

Highyeild:

Common cause of puberty menorrhagia Anovulatory cycles —>unopposed estrogen→ endometrial hyperplasia →prolonged and heavy periods Other causes: Endocrine dysfunction: Pcos Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism Hematological Immune thrombocytopenic purpura Von willebrand disease leukemia Pelvic tumors Fibroid uterus Sarcoma botryoides Pregnancy complication- abortion Treatment modality Reassurance and psychological support Rest and correction of anemia In emergency conjugated equine estrogen for every 6-8 hours Once bleeding control combined oral pills are started. Regular menstrual cycle will be established once the hypothalamo-pituitary -ovarian axes is matured.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B. Primary amenorrhea : Clinical presentation is amenorrhea or absence of menstruation rather than menorrhagia which is excessive menstruation. Option C. Endometriosis: Endometriosis is the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue away from the cavity of the uterus. • Adenomyosis is ectopic endometrial tissue within the wall of the uterus Option D. Malignancy: Menorrhagia due to malignancy is rare but may occur in women with chronic anovulation.
